overview: From 2026-01-31 to 2026-02-01, elizaos-plugins/plugin-mcp had 2 new PRs (3 merged), 0 new issues, and 3 active contributors.

topPRs.title: feat!: Dynamic MCP tool actions (v1.8.0)
topPRs.author: 0xbbjoker
topPRs.body:
## Summary - **BREAKING**: Transform MCP tools from single `CALL_MCP_TOOL` action to dynamically registered native ElizaOS actions - Reduces LLM calls from 3 to 1 per MCP tool invocation - Add optional Redis caching for MCP tool schemas (set `MCP_CACHE_REDIS_URL` to Upstash REST URL) - Add comprehensive test suite (204 tests, 388 assertions) ## Changes ### New Architecture - `dynamic-tool-actions.ts` - Factory for converting MCP tools to ElizaOS actions - `schema-converter.ts` - JSON Schema to ActionParameter conversion - `action-naming.ts` - Consistent action naming with collision avoidance - `schema-cache.ts` - Redis caching layer for tool schemas ### Tool Compatibility Refactor - Extract base class to `base.ts` to break circular dependencies - Use static imports instead of `eval('require')` for ESM compatibility - Properly detect and handle reasoning models (o1, o3) ### Bug Fixes - Fix `parseJSON` to handle arrays and use bracket depth counting - Fix `hashConfig` to recursively sort nested objects - Fix validation to fail on missing required parameters (was logging only) - Fix `processToolResult` to generate unique attachment IDs ### Code Quality - Remove ~1000 lines of dead/over-engineered code - Delete unused `McpError` class with 5 factory methods - Consolidate 4 separate constraint interfaces into inline types - Add error logging to previously silent catch blocks ## Test plan - [x] All 204 tests pass locally - [x] Tested on eliza-cloud-v2 - works correctly - [x] MCP tools register as native actions - [x] Tool invocation works with single LLM call ü§ñ Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.com/claude-code) --- > [!NOTE] > **High Risk** > High risk because this is a breaking change that rewires MCP tool invocation and mutates runtime action registration, plus adds new caching/lazy-connection paths that can affect startup and tool availability. > > **Overview** > **BREAKING:** Removes the monolithic `CALL_MCP_TOOL` action and instead dynamically registers one native ElizaOS action per MCP tool (with generated names/similes, schema-derived `parameters`, and runtime param validation) so tool execution no longer depends on an LLM tool-selection/argument step. > > Adds an optional Upstash REST schema cache (`McpSchemaCache`) and *lazy connection* behavior: tool schemas can be loaded from cache and actions registered without connecting to MCP until first use; `McpService` is refactored accordingly (connect/disconnect, action (un)registration, updated ping/reconnect handling). > > Includes supporting utilities/refactors (schema conversion, action naming, simplified tool-compatibility exports/detection, improved JSON extraction and attachment IDs, streamlined error/processing code), removes legacy selection/templates/helpers, bumps to `1.8.0`, and adds comprehensive Bun tests. > > Written by [Cursor Bugbot](https://cursor.com/dashboard?tab=bugbot) for commit ecd270a78f21cb48cc60a9c6dbf953e8f6411f92. This will update automatically on new commits. Configure [here](https://cursor.com/dashboard?tab=bugbot). ## Summary by CodeRabbit * **New Features** * Dynamic MCP tool actions with automatic parameter mapping and runtime validation * Optional schema cache to speed tool discovery and cold starts * Schema-to-action parameter conversion utilities * **Improvements** * Service lifecycle refactor for explicit init, lazy connections, and safer startup * Streamlined tool-compatibility and parsing logic; improved error fallback behavior * **Removed** * Several legacy templates and selection/feedback helpers removed * **Version** * Bumped to 1.8.0 * **Tests** * Extensive new unit and integration tests covering actions, caching, parsing, and processing ‚úèÔ∏è Tip: You can customize this high-level summary in your review settings.

Greptile Overview

Greptile Summary

This PR transforms the MCP plugin architecture from a multi-step tool invocation pattern to native dynamic action registration, achieving significant performance improvements and code quality gains. ## Key Changes **Breaking Architecture Change:** - Removed single `CALL_MCP_TOOL` action that required 3 LLM calls (tool selection ‚Üí argument generation ‚Üí execution) - Replaced with dynamically registered native ElizaOS actions for each MCP tool (1 LLM call per invocation) - Each MCP tool now appears as a first-class action with proper parameters, validation, and metadata **Performance Optimizations:** - Added optional Redis schema caching via Upstash REST API (set `MCP_CACHE_REDIS_URL` to enable) - Caches tool schemas with config hash validation to avoid MCP connection on cold starts - Lazy connection support: registers actions from cache before establishing actual MCP connection **Bug Fixes:** - Fixed `parseJSON` to handle arrays and use bracket depth counting instead of regex - Fixed `hashConfig` to recursively sort object keys for consistent hashing - Fixed validation to properly fail on missing required parameters (was only logging warnings) - Fixed `processToolResult` to generate unique attachment IDs using incrementing index **Code Quality Improvements:** - Removed ~1,000 lines of dead/over-engineered code - Deleted unused `McpError` class with 5 factory methods - Consolidated 4 separate constraint interfaces into inline types - Extracted base class to break circular dependencies in tool-compatibility - Replaced `eval('require')` with static imports for ESM compatibility - Added error logging to previously silent catch blocks **Testing:** - Added comprehensive test suite: 204 tests with 388 assertions - Tests cover action creation, schema conversion, caching, JSON parsing, and integration scenarios - 63 tests pass in isolated environment (others require `@elizaos/core` dependency)

Confidence Score: 5/5

- This PR is safe to merge with minimal risk - well-tested breaking change with clear migration path - The breaking change is intentional and well-documented. The refactor removes significant amounts of dead code, adds comprehensive test coverage (204 tests), includes important bug fixes, and demonstrates successful deployment on eliza-cloud-v2. The architectural change from 3 LLM calls to 1 is a significant improvement that justifies the breaking change marker. - No files require special attention - the refactor is well-structured with comprehensive test coverage

Important Files Changed

| Filename | Overview | |----------|----------| | src/actions/dynamic-tool-actions.ts | New factory for converting MCP tools to native ElizaOS actions - clean implementation with proper validation and error handling | | src/utils/schema-converter.ts | Converts JSON Schema to ActionParameter format with comprehensive validation and type mapping | | src/cache/schema-cache.ts | Optional Redis caching for tool schemas with graceful fallback - includes config hash validation | | src/service.ts | Major refactor to register MCP tools as native actions, adds cache support, removes ~500 lines of dead code | | src/utils/json.ts | Fixed parseJSON to handle arrays and use bracket depth counting instead of regex | | src/utils/processing.ts | Fixed processToolResult to generate unique attachment IDs using incrementing index | | src/tool-compatibility/base.ts | Extracted base class to break circular dependencies, uses static imports for ESM compatibility |

Sequence Diagram

```mermaid sequenceDiagram participant User participant Runtime participant McpService participant Cache as SchemaCache participant MCP as MCP Server participant Action as Dynamic Action Note over Runtime,McpService: Initialization (Cold Start) Runtime->>McpService: start() McpService->>Cache: getSchemas(agentId, serverName, hash) alt Cache Hit Cache-->>McpService: Return cached tools McpService->>McpService: registerToolsAsActions() McpService->>McpService: Store lazy connection config Note over McpService: Server not connected yet else Cache Miss McpService->>MCP: connect() MCP-->>McpService: Return tools McpService->>McpService: registerToolsAsActions() McpService->>Cache: setSchemas(agentId, serverName, hash, tools) end McpService-->>Runtime: Ready (actions registered) Note over User,Action: Tool Invocation (1 LLM call) User->>Runtime: "Use search tool with query=hello" Runtime->>Runtime: LLM selects GOOGLE_SEARCH action Runtime->>Action: handler(runtime, message, state) Action->>Action: extractParams(message, state) Action->>Action: validateParamsAgainstSchema(params) alt Lazy Connection Action->>McpService: callTool() triggers connection McpService->>MCP: connect() MCP-->>McpService: Connected end Action->>McpService: callTool(serverName, toolName, params) McpService->>MCP: Execute tool MCP-->>McpService: Tool result McpService-->>Action: Result with content Action->>Action: processToolResult() Action-->>Runtime: ActionResult Runtime-->>User: Response with tool output ```

topPRs.title: feat: add StreamableHTTP transport and code quality improvements
topPRs.author: 0xbbjoker
topPRs.body:
## Summary - Add `StreamableHTTPClientTransport` for non-SSE HTTP connections (avoids Redis requirement) - Add `headers` support for HTTP transports (enables auth header injection) - Simplify error handling with `errMsg` helper (deduplicated 10+ patterns) - Clean up verbose logging and redundant code (~250 lines removed) - Fix `restartConnection` to throw on missing connection (was silently failing) ## Test plan - [x] Build passes - [ ] Test with streamable-http MCP server - [ ] Test with SSE MCP server - [ ] Verify header injection works for authenticated endpoints ü§ñ Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.com/claude-code) --- > [!NOTE] > **Medium Risk** > Touches MCP connection/transport initialization, timeouts, and reconnection behavior, so failures could break tool availability or change runtime error handling. Changes are contained to the MCP plugin but impact all tool calls over HTTP/SSE. > > **Overview** > Adds `StreamableHTTPClientTransport` support for HTTP MCP servers (defaulting non-`sse` HTTP configs to streamable HTTP) and allows optional per-server `headers` to be sent on transport creation for authenticated endpoints. > > Tightens and simplifies `McpService` lifecycle/robustness: explicit 60s connect timeout, clearer error formatting via `errMsg`, ping monitoring only for `stdio` transports, and `restartConnection` now throws if the server isn‚Äôt connected. Provider fetching now waits for MCP initialization and returns a consistent empty provider when unavailable; provider/memory text formatting and `CALL_MCP_TOOL` action logging were also refined, and the package version bumps to `1.7.1`. > > Written by [Cursor Bugbot](https://cursor.com/dashboard?tab=bugbot) for commit 57e0d018919af2cdc43dd67da3f52aca4037cc6e. This will update automatically on new commits. Configure [here](https://cursor.com/dashboard?tab=bugbot). ## Summary by CodeRabbit * **New Features** * Returns a default provider when MCP services are unavailable and improves provider summaries. * **Bug Fixes** * More resilient per-server connection handling and graceful behavior when servers are missing. * Improved error reporting, timeout handling, and connection lifecycle stability. * **Chores** * Bumped package version to 1.7.1. * Refined provider, memory and textual summaries for clearer display. ‚úèÔ∏è Tip: You can customize this high-level summary in your review settings.

Greptile Overview

Greptile Summary

This PR adds `StreamableHTTPClientTransport` support for non-SSE HTTP connections, enables custom header injection for authentication, and performs significant code cleanup. **Major changes:** - Added `StreamableHTTPClientTransport` as an alternative to SSE (avoids Redis dependency) - Added `headers` field to `HttpMcpServerConfig` for authentication token injection - Introduced `errMsg` helper to standardize error message extraction (~10+ patterns deduplicated) - Removed ~250 lines of verbose logging and redundant code - Fixed `restartConnection` to throw when connection is missing (previously silent failure) - Added 60s timeout to connection initialization with `Promise.race` - Simplified provider data building and error handling **Issues found:** - `src/types.ts` is missing the `StreamableHTTPClientTransport` import and type union update - this will cause TypeScript compilation errors - Some catch blocks silently swallow errors without logging (minor debugging impact) - `errMsg` helper is defined before imports (style inconsistency) The changes align well with the stated goals of reducing Redis requirements and enabling authenticated MCP endpoints. The code quality improvements make the codebase more maintainable.

Confidence Score: 2/5

- TypeScript compilation will fail due to missing type imports and union update in types.ts - The PR introduces critical type errors that will prevent compilation - StreamableHTTPClientTransport is used but not imported in types.ts, and the McpConnection.transport union type is incomplete. While the logic changes are sound and well-tested according to the test plan, the type system errors must be fixed before merge. - Fix `src/types.ts` to add StreamableHTTPClientTransport import and update the transport union type on line 74

Important Files Changed

| Filename | Overview | |----------|----------| | src/types.ts | Added headers support to HttpMcpServerConfig, but missing StreamableHTTPClientTransport import and type union update | | src/service.ts | Added StreamableHTTPClientTransport support, errMsg helper, code cleanup. Error helper defined before imports, some silent error catches could use logging |

Sequence Diagram

```mermaid sequenceDiagram participant Client as ElizaOS Client participant Service as McpService participant Transport as StreamableHTTPClientTransport participant Server as MCP Server Client->>Service: initializeMcpServers() Service->>Service: getMcpSettings() Service->>Service: updateServerConnections(configs) loop For each server config Service->>Service: initializeConnection(name, config) Service->>Service: buildHttpClientTransport(name, config) alt config.type === 'sse' Service->>Transport: new SSEClientTransport(url, opts) Note over Service: Warns: SSE requires Redis else config.type === 'http' | 'streamable-http' Service->>Transport: new StreamableHTTPClientTransport(url, opts) Note over Transport: Supports custom headers for auth end Service->>Transport: client.connect(transport) Transport->>Server: HTTP Connection (with headers) Server-->>Transport: Connection established Service->>Server: fetchToolsList() Server-->>Service: Tools list Service->>Server: fetchResourcesList() Server-->>Service: Resources list Service->>Service: startPingMonitoring() Note over Service: Only for stdio, HTTP is stateless end Service->>Service: buildMcpProviderData(servers) Service-->>Client: Initialization complete Client->>Service: callTool(serverName, toolName, args) Service->>Transport: client.callTool(request, timeout) Transport->>Server: HTTP Request (with auth headers) Server-->>Transport: Tool result Transport-->>Service: CallToolResult Service-->>Client: Result ```

topPRs.title: feat: implement StreamableHTTP transport and custom headers for HTTP connections
topPRs.author: BaseGold
topPRs.body:
## Summary `buildHttpClientTransport` currently returns `SSEClientTransport` for all HTTP transport types (`"http"`, `"streamable-http"`, `"sse"`), despite the README and type definitions advertising Streamable HTTP support. This PR implements the actual transport routing and adds custom headers passthrough. ## Key Changes ### Streamable HTTP Transport Support - Use `StreamableHTTPClientTransport` from `@modelcontextprotocol/sdk` for `"http"` and `"streamable-http"` types - Keep `SSEClientTransport` only for legacy `"sse"` type - Aligns runtime behavior with the documented config and `HttpMcpServerConfig` type definition **Before:** ```typescript // Always returns SSE regardless of config type return new SSEClientTransport(new URL(config.url)); ``` **After:** ```typescript if (config.type === 'sse') { return new SSEClientTransport(new URL(config.url), { requestInit }); } return new StreamableHTTPClientTransport(new URL(config.url), { requestInit }); ``` ### Custom Headers Support - Added `headers?: Record` to `HttpMcpServerConfig` - Passed through to both transports via `requestInit` - Enables `Authorization`, API key headers, and other custom headers without workarounds ```json { "my-server": { "type": "http", "url": "https://example.com/mcp", "headers": { "Authorization": "Bearer my-api-key" } } } ``` ### Type Updates - Added `StreamableHTTPClientTransport` to `McpConnection.transport` union type - Updated local type annotations in `initializeConnection` ## Impact - **Correctness**: `type: "http"` now actually uses Streamable HTTP instead of SSE - **No breaking changes**: `type: "sse"` behavior is unchanged - **Headers**: Allow authenticated MCP server connections using headers ## Summary by CodeRabbit * **New Features** * Introduced StreamableHTTPClientTransport as a new option for HTTP and streamable-HTTP MCP server connections * HTTP server configurations now support optional custom headers for authentication and advanced use cases ‚úèÔ∏è Tip: You can customize this high-level summary in your review settings.

Greptile Overview

Greptile Summary

Implements actual Streamable HTTP transport routing that was previously advertised but not working - `type: "http"` and `type: "streamable-http"` now correctly use `StreamableHTTPClientTransport` instead of incorrectly using `SSEClientTransport` for all HTTP types. - Fixes critical bug where all HTTP transport types were using SSE transport regardless of config - Adds `headers` field to `HttpMcpServerConfig` for passing custom headers (Authorization, API keys, etc.) to both transport types - Maintains backward compatibility by keeping `type: "sse"` working with `SSEClientTransport` - Updates type definitions to include `StreamableHTTPClientTransport` in union types The changes align runtime behavior with documented config options in README and type definitions. No breaking changes - existing SSE configs continue working with deprecation warning.

Confidence Score: 5/5

- Safe to merge - fixes documented behavior, maintains backward compatibility, no breaking changes - Clean implementation that fixes a critical correctness bug where documented transport types weren't working. The code properly routes to correct transport classes, passes headers through standard RequestInit interface, preserves legacy SSE support with deprecation warning, and includes appropriate logging. Type definitions are properly updated. - No files require special attention

Important Files Changed

| Filename | Overview | |----------|----------| | src/types.ts | Added `StreamableHTTPClientTransport` to type unions and `headers` field to HTTP config - clean type additions | | src/service.ts | Implemented proper transport routing: `StreamableHTTPClientTransport` for http/streamable-http, `SSEClientTransport` only for legacy sse |

Sequence Diagram

```mermaid sequenceDiagram participant Client as McpService participant Builder as buildHttpClientTransport participant SSE as SSEClientTransport participant Streamable as StreamableHTTPClientTransport participant Server as MCP Server Client->>Builder: buildHttpClientTransport(config) alt config.type === 'sse' Builder->>Builder: Log deprecation warning Builder->>SSE: new SSEClientTransport(url, {requestInit}) Note over SSE: Legacy transport
for backward compatibility SSE-->>Builder: transport instance else config.type === 'http' OR 'streamable-http' Builder->>Builder: Log: using Streamable HTTP Builder->>Streamable: new StreamableHTTPClientTransport(url, {requestInit}) Note over Streamable: Modern transport
with custom headers support Streamable-->>Builder: transport instance end Builder-->>Client: return transport Client->>Server: client.connect(transport) Note over Client,Server: Headers from config.headers
passed via requestInit ``` (2/5) Greptile learns from your feedback when you react with thumbs up/down!

topContributors.summary: 0xbbjoker: Focused on significant feature development and code quality improvements within the `elizaos-plugins/plugin-mcp` repository, merging two substantial pull requests, including "feat!: Dynamic MCP tool actions (v1.8.0)" (#22) with over 4000 lines of changes, and "feat: add StreamableHTTP transport and code quality improvements" (#21).
